question: Taking into account the information outlined in the P&L statement and the statement of financial position, what is 3M's FY2018 fixed asset turnover ratio? Fixed asset turnover ratio is defined as: FY2018 revenue / (average PP&E between FY2017 and FY2018). Round your answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio, we first need to find the average Property, Plant, and Equipment (PP&E) for both years.

Average PP&E = (Beginning PP&E + Ending PP&E) / 2

For FY2017: Average PP&E = ($24,873 + $24,914) / 2 = $24,893.7
For FY2018: Average PP&E = ($24,914 + $24,873) / 2 = $24,893.7

Now that we have the average PP&E for both years, we can calculate the Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio using the revenue from the P&L statement:

Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio = Revenue / Average PP&E

For FY2018, the revenue is not provided in the information you've given. To find the Fixed Asset Turnover Ratio, we would need to know the total revenue for FY2018.

contexts:
Entry into a Material Definitive Agreement.
 
On April 26, 2022, Amcor plc (the Company), as parent guarantor, entered into a (i) Three-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement (the
Three-Year Agreement) with Amcor Pty Ltd (Amcor Australia), Amcor Finance (USA), Inc., (AFUI), Amcor UK Finance plc (Amcor
UK) and Amcor Flexibles North America, Inc. (AFNA and, together with Amcor Australia, AFUI and Amcor UK, the Borrowers), the
lenders party thereto and JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. (JP Morgan), as administrative agent and foreign administrative agent, and (ii) Five-
Year Syndicated Facility Agreement (the Five-Year Agreement and, together with the Three-Year Agreement, the Agreements) with the
Borrowers, the lenders party thereto and JPMorgan, as administrative agent and foreign administrative agent.
 
Each of the Three-Year Agreement and the Five-Year Agreement provides for a revolving credit facility in an aggregate committed
amount of $1.875 billion, each of which is unsecured, and scheduled to mature on April 26, 2025 and April 26, 2027, respectively, which date
may be extended under the Agreements by one year at the Companys option, subject to certain conditions set forth in the Agreements. Subject to
obtaining commitments from existing or new lenders and certain other conditions, the Company may, at any time and from time to time by
written notice to JP Morgan, request an increase in the total aggregate commitment level under each Agreement by up to $500.0 million. At
closing, the Company did not draw down any amounts pursuant to the Agreements.
 
Under the Agreements, each loan which is an alternate base rate loan will bear interest at a rate per annum equal to Alternate Base Rate
(as defined in the Agreements), plus an applicable rate ranging from 0.0% to 0.50%, depending on the Companys credit rating. Each loan which
is a term SOFR loan will bear interest at a rate per annum equal to the Adjusted Term SOFR Rate (as defined in the Agreements), plus an
applicable rate ranging from 0.875% to 1.50%, depending on the Companys credit rating. Each loan which is an EURIBOR revolving loan will
bear interest at a rate per annum equal to the Adjusted EURIBO Rate (as defined in the Agreements), plus an applicable rate ranging from
0.875% to 1.50%, depending on the Companys credit rating. Each loan which is a RFR (as defined in the Agreements) revolving loan and each
loan which is a swingline loan will bear interest at a rate per annum equal to the Daily Simple RFR (as defined in the Agreements), plus an
applicable rate ranging from 0.875% to 1.50%, depending on the Companys credit rating.
 
The Agreements also contain customary affirmative and negative covenants, financial covenants, representations and warranties, events
of default and other provisions.
 
The foregoing summary of the Agreements does not purport to be complete, and is subject to and is qualified in its entirety by the terms
of each of the Three-Year Agreement and the Five-Year Agreement, which are attached hereto as Exhibit 10.1 and 10.2, respectively, and each of
which is incorporated herein by reference.
 
Item 1.02.
Termination of a Material Definitive Agreement.
 
On April 26, 2022, the Company terminated each of its (i) Three-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement (as amended to date, the
Previous Three-Year Agreement), dated as of April 30, 2019, by and among the Company, the Borrowers, the lenders party thereto and
JPMorgan, as administrative agent and foreign administrative agent, (ii) Four-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement (as amended to date, the
Previous Four-Year Agreement), dated as of April 30, 2019, by and among the Company, the Borrowers, the lenders party thereto and
JPMorgan, as administrative agent and foreign administrative agent, and (iii) Five-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement (as amended to date, the
Previous Five-Year Agreement and, together with the Previous Three-Year Agreement and the Previous Four-Year Agreement, the Previous
Agreements), dated as of April 30, 2019, by and among the Company, the Borrowers, the lenders party thereto and JPMorgan, as administrative
agent and foreign administrative agent. There were no amounts outstanding under the Previous Agreements as of April 26, 2022, and the
Company did not incur any early termination penalties in connection with the termination of the Previous Agreements.
 
The Previous Agreements consisted of a three-year $750 million multi-currency credit facility expiring in April 2023, a four-year $1.50
billion multi-currency credit facility expiring in April 2024 and a five-year $1.50 billion multi-currency credit facility expiring in April 2025.
question: What was the key agenda of the 8k filing dated 26th April 2022 for AMCOR?
ground_truth: #NAME?
label: PASS
answer: The key agenda of the 8-K filing dated April 26, 2022, for Amcor was the termination of its Three-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement, Four-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement, and Five-Year Syndicated Facility Agreement. These agreements were terminated without any outstanding amounts or early termination penalties.

question: What is AES's three year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a % of revenue from FY2018 to FY2020? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place. Please base your judgments on the information provided primarily in the income statement and the cash flow statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the three-year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue, we first need to calculate the total depreciation and amortization expense for each year and then find their average.

1. Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2018):
   From the provided income statement, there is no separate line item for depreciation and amortization. However, we can calculate it by finding the difference between total revenue and operating margin, as operating margin includes all expenses except depreciation and amortization.

   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2018) = Total Revenue (2018) - Operating Margin (2018)
   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2018) = 10,736 - 2,573 = 8,163 million dollars

2. Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2019):
   Similar to the previous year, we can calculate depreciation and amortization expense for 2019 by finding the difference between total revenue and operating margin.

   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2019) = Total Revenue (2019) - Operating Margin (2019)
   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2019) = 10,189 - 2,349 = 7,840 million dollars

3. Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2020):
   Again, we can calculate depreciation and amortization expense for 2020 by finding the difference between total revenue and operating margin.

   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2020) = Total Revenue (2020) - Operating Margin (2020)
   Depreciation and Amortization Expense (2020) = 9,660 - 2,693 = 6,967 million dollars

4. Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense:
   To find the average, we sum up the depreciation and amortization expense for each year and divide by the number of years (3).

   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense = (8,163 + 7,840 + 6,967) / 3
   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense = 22,970 million dollars / 3
   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense ≈ 7,323.33 million dollars per year

5. Average as a percentage of revenue:
   To find the average depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue, we divide the average depreciation and amortization expense by the total revenue for each year and then take the average.

   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense as a percentage of revenue = (Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense / Total Revenue (2018)) + ((Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense / Total Revenue (2019)) + ((Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense / Total Revenue (2020))) / 3
   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense as a percentage of revenue = (7,323.33 million dollars / 10,736 million dollars) + ((7,323.33 million dollars / 10,189 million dollars) + ((7,323.33 million dollars / 9,660 million dollars)) / 3
   Average Depreciation and Amortization Expense as a percentage of revenue ≈ 0.68 or approximately 68% (rounded to one decimal place)

question: When primarily referencing the statement of cash flows and the income statement, what is MGM Resorts's FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA (using unadjusted operating income and D&A from cash flow statement) % margin?
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, Amortization, and other adjustments), we need to find the Operating Income (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes - EBIT) and add back Depreciation and Amortization (D&A).

   From the cash flow statement provided, the Operating Income is 1,373,423. The D&A for the year can be found in the same statement under "Amortization of debt discounts, premiums and issuance costs" and "Provision for credit losses".

   Adding up these two line items gives us a total D&A of 76,593 (40,328 + 34,363 + 38,972 + 21,852 + 39,270).

   Now we can calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA:

   1,373,423 (Operating Income) + 76,593 (D&A) = 1,449,916

   To find the EBITDA Margin, we divide the Unadjusted EBITDA by Total Revenue and multiply by 100:

   First, let's find the total revenue. In this case, it is not explicitly provided in the data you have given. However, if we assume that the number 3,940,215 is the total revenue for the year (which seems plausible as it appears to be a line item related to non-operating income), then:

   EBITDA Margin = (Unadjusted EBITDA / Total Revenue) * 100

   EBITDA Margin = (1,449,916 / 3,940,215) * 100 ≈ 36.78%

   Keep in mind that this calculation assumes the total revenue is 3,940,215, which may not be accurate based on the data provided. If the actual total revenue is different, the EBITDA margin will also change accordingly.

question: What is the FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA (using unadjusted operating income + D&A from cash flow statement) for Activision Blizzard? Answer in USD billions. Address the question by using the line items and information shown within the statement of income and the statement of cash flows.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization) for Activision Blizzard, we need to find the operating income and add back depreciation and amortization expenses from the cash flow statement.

From the provided statements:
- Operating Income for FY2021 is $3,164 million (or 3,164,000 thousand)
- Depreciation and Amortization (D&A) can be found in the cash flow statement under "Cash Flows from Operating Activities" as "Depreciation and amortization expense." For FY2021, it is $965 million + $233 million = $1,208 million (or 1,208,000 thousand)

Now, let's calculate the unadjusted EBITDA:
- Unadjusted EBITDA = Operating Income + Depreciation and Amortization Expense
- Unadjusted EBITDA = $3,164 million + $1,208 million = $4,372 million (or 4,372,000 thousand)

So, the FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA for Activision Blizzard is approximately $4.372 billion.

question: When primarily referencing the P&L statement, what is the FY2017 COGS as a % of total revenue for Adobe?
label: PASS
answer: The COGS (Cost of Revenue) for FY2017 was $1,010,491. The total revenue for FY2017 was $6,291,014. To find the percentage, divide the cost of revenue by the total revenue and multiply by 100. So, COGS as a % of total revenue is approximately 16.03%.

question: When primarily referencing the income statement, how much (in USD millions) was Oracle's FY2016 selling, general, and administrative expense?
label: PASS
answer:
To find the Selling, General, and Administrative (SG&A) expense for Oracle in FY2016, we need to add up the expenses listed under "Research and development" and "General and administrative". From the provided data, these amounts are:

* Research and development: $5,151 + $5,524 + $5,151 = $15,826 million
* General and administrative: $1,038 + $1,077 + $1,077 + $1,155 = $4,347 million

Adding these two amounts together gives us the total SG&A expense for FY2016:

$15,826 (Research and development) + $4,347 (General and administrative) = $20,173 million

So, Oracle's FY2016 Selling, General, and Administrative expense was approximately $20.173 billion.

label: PASS
answer: The Asset Turnover Ratio for Netflix in FY2020 is approximately 1.34 (Revenue for FY2020: $24,996,056 / Average Total Assets between FY2019 and FY2020: ($(6,178,504 + 39,280,359) / 2) = 1.34).

question: What is Kraft Heinz's FY2019 depreciation and amortization expense (as shown in cash flow statement) divided by total revenue (as a %, rounded to one decimal place)? Address the question by using the line items and information shown within the statement of income and the cash flow statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To find Kraft Heinz's FY2019 depreciation and amortization expense, we need to look for the line item "Depreciation and Amortization" in the Statement of Income (also known as the Income Statement). However, the information provided does not include a statement of income.

   To find Kraft Heinz's total revenue, we can use the line item "Net cash provided by/(used for) operating activities" in the Cash Flow Statement, which represents net income before interest and taxes. We then need to adjust this figure to account for changes in working capital (inventory, accounts payable, and other current assets/liabilities), as well as gains or losses from investing and financing activities.

   Since we don't have the exact line items for changes in working capital and non-cash investing activities, it is not possible to accurately calculate Kraft Heinz's FY2019 depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of total revenue using only the information provided.

   To get accurate figures, you should refer to Kraft Heinz's complete financial statements or annual report, which can be found on their official website or through financial databases like Yahoo Finance or EDGAR Online.

question: What is American Water Works's 2 year total revenue CAGR from FY2015 to FY2017 (in units of percents and round to one decimal place)? Address the question by using the line items and information shown within the statement of income.
label: PASS
answer: The 2-year Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) for American Water Works's total revenue from FY2015 to FY2017 is approximately 1.3%. To calculate this, use the formula: ((Final value - Initial value) / (Initial value * Time in years)) ^ (1 / Time in years). In this case, the final value is $3,357 (FY2017), the initial value is $3,159 (FY2015), and the time in years is 2.

contexts:
We have deep capabilities in materials science, optical design, shaping, coating, finishing, metrology and optical system assembly. Our products and capabilities in this
segment position us to meet the needs of a broad array of markets, including semiconductor, aerospace, defense, industrial, commercial and telecommunications. Our
principal competitors include Schott AG, AGC Inc., Nippon Electric Glass Co., Ltd. and Heraeus.
question: What is Corning's competition landscape and positioning in the Specialty Materials Segment?
ground_truth: Corning maintains a competitive position in this segment; although, the landscape has a lot of strong competitors who dominate the segment.
label: PASS
answer:
Competition Landscape: Schott AG, AGC Inc., Nippon Electric Glass Co., Ltd., and Heraeus.
   Positioning: Corning operates within the Specialty Materials Segment, catering to various markets such as semiconductor, aerospace, defense, industrial, commercial, and telecommunications.

question: By relying on the line items plainly stated within the cash flow statement and the P&L statement, what is the FY2018 - FY2020 3 year average of capex as a % of revenue for General Mills? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the 3-year average Capex (Capital Expenditures) as a percentage of revenue for General Mills, we first need to calculate the total capex for each year and then find the average.

1. Calculate Capex for each year:
   - FY2018: Sum of all negative numbers under "Cash Flows - Investing Activities" except for "Proceeds from disposal of land, buildings, and equipment". In this case, it's (486.2) + (556.5) + (8,685.4) = $9,708.1
   - FY2019: Sum of all negative numbers under "Cash Flows - Investing Activities" except for "Proceeds from disposal of land, buildings, and equipment". In this case, it's (556.5) + (8,685.4) = $9,241.9
   - FY2020: Sum of all negative numbers under "Cash Flows - Investing Activities" except for "Proceeds from disposal of land, buildings, and equipment". In this case, it's (8,685.4) = $8,685.4

2. Calculate the total revenue for each year:
   - FY2018: Not provided in the given data, but you can find it from the income statement or another reliable source.
   - FY2019: Total Revenue is $36,754 million (as per the provided P&L statement)
   - FY2020: Total Revenue is $38,600 million (as per the provided P&L statement)

3. Calculate the average Capex as a percentage of revenue for the 3-year period:
   - Average Capex/Revenue = (Sum of Capex for each year / Number of years) * 100%
   - Average Capex/Revenue = ((9,708.1 + 9,241.9 + 8,685.4) / 3) * 100% = $9,124.2 / 3 * 100% ≈ 30.41% (rounded to one decimal place)

So the FY2018 - FY2020 3-year average of Capex as a percentage of revenue for General Mills is approximately 30.41%.

Since this information is not given, I'm unable to provide an answer.

question: What is Amazon's FY2022 interest coverage ratio? Define interest coverage ratio as: (unadjusted operating income [from income statement] + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]) / gross interest expense [from income statement]). Round answer to two decimal places. Give a response to the question by relying on the details shown in the P&L statement and the cash flow statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate Amazon's FY2022 interest coverage ratio, we first need to find the unadjusted operating income (EBIT) and gross interest expense from the provided statements.

1. EBIT: Operating Income + Depreciation and Amortization
   - For Year 1: 22,899 + 363,165 = $386,064
   - For Year 2: 24,879 + 444,943 = $470,822
   - For Year 3: 12,248 + 501,735 = $514,983

2. Gross Interest Expense: Interest expense from the income statement
   - For Year 1: (1,647)
   - For Year 2: (1,809)
   - For Year 3: (2,367)

Now we can calculate the interest coverage ratio for each year:

- Year 1: ($386,064 + $363,165) / (1,647) = 292.63
- Year 2: ($470,822 + $444,943) / (1,809) = 325.49
- Year 3: ($514,983 + $501,735) / (2,367) = 220.31

Since we are looking for the FY2022 interest coverage ratio, the answer is approximately 325.49 (rounded to two decimal places). This means that Amazon's FY2022 interest coverage ratio is 325.49.

question: What is the FY2017 - FY2018 change in unadjusted EBITDA % margin for Block (formerly known as Square)? Calculate unadjusted EBITDA using unadjusted operating income and D&A (from cash flow statement). Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place. Please base your judgments on the information provided primarily in the statement of income and the statement of cash flows.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the change in unadjusted EBITDA % margin for Block (formerly known as Square) from FY2017 to FY2018, we first need to find the unadjusted EBITDA for both years.

   Unadjusted EBITDA = Operating Income + Depreciation and Amortization (D&A)

   For FY2017:
   - Operating Income: $(62,664) (from the statement of income)
   - D&A: $883 + $850 = $1,733 (from the cash flow statement under "Amortization of acquired customer assets")
   So, Unadjusted EBITDA for FY2017 = $(62,664) + $1,733 = $(-60,931)

   For FY2018:
   - Operating Income: $(36,127) (from the statement of income)
   - D&A: $883 + $850 = $1,733 (from the cash flow statement under "Amortization of acquired customer assets")
   So, Unadjusted EBITDA for FY2018 = $(36,127) + $1,733 = $(-37,860)

   Now that we have the unadjusted EBITDA for both years, we can calculate the change in unadjusted EBITDA % margin:

   (Unadjusted EBITDA FY2018 - Unadjusted EBITDA FY2017) / Unadjusted Revenue FY2017 * 100%

   (-$37,860 - $(-60,931)) / $2,214,253 * 100% = -43.24%

   So, the change in unadjusted EBITDA % margin for Block (formerly known as Square) from FY2017 to FY2018 was a decrease of approximately 43.24%.

contexts:
Our Digital Experience business unit competes in markets that are growing rapidly and characterized by intense 
competition. Our Adobe Experience Cloud solutions face competition from large, established companies, including large 
enterprise software, internet and database management companies, in addition to point product solutions and focused 
competitors, and new competitors are constantly entering these markets. Some of these competitors provide SaaS solutions to 
customers, generally through a web browser, while others provide software that is installed by customers directly on their 
servers. In addition, we compete at times with our customers or potential customers internally-developed applications.
question: How would you describe Adobe's competitive landscape for Digital Experience as of FY2022?
ground_truth: Highly competitive with many competitors entering the market constantly. Additionally, all these companies enhance digital experience in various and diverse ways, such as SaaS, plug-ins, softwares, etc.
label: PASS
answer: Intense and dynamic, characterized by competition from large established companies, point product solutions, focused competitors, SaaS providers, and new entrants in the market. Competition also comes from customers' internally-developed applications.

question: By relying on the line items plainly stated within the statement of income and the cash flow statement, what is Corning's three year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a % of revenue from FY2017 to FY2019? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the three-year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue, we first need to determine the total depreciation and amortization expense for each year and then calculate the average.

From the provided statement of income, we can see that the line item "Depreciation and Amortization" is not explicitly stated. However, we can find it by subtracting the net income (loss) from the total operating expenses.

Let's denote:
- Net Income (Loss) as NI
- Total Operating Expenses as OE
- Revenue as R

For FY2019, we have:
NI = $960
OE = Total operating expenses are not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Cost of sales, Selling, general and administrative expenses, Research and development expenses, Other operating income (expense), net. From the provided statement, these amounts are $3,578 + $1,462 + $1,096 + $1,000 + $48 = $7,624
R = Total revenue is not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Net sales and Other revenue. From the provided statement, these amounts are $15,430 + $1,000 = $16,430

So, Depreciation and Amortization (DA) for FY2019 is:
DA = OE - NI = $7,624 - $960 = $6,664

Similarly, we can find the Depreciation and Amortization for FY2018 and FY2017.

For FY2018:
NI = $1,066
OE = Total operating expenses are not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Cost of sales, Selling, general and administrative expenses, Research and development expenses, Other operating income (expense), net. From the provided statement, these amounts are $3,578 + $1,462 + $1,096 + $1,000 + $58 = $6,704
R = Total revenue is not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Net sales and Other revenue. From the provided statement, these amounts are $13,996 + $1,000 = $14,996
So, Depreciation and Amortization for FY2018 is:
DA = OE - NI = $6,704 - $1,066 = $5,638

For FY2017:
NI = $(497)
OE = Total operating expenses are not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Cost of sales, Selling, general and administrative expenses, Research and development expenses, Other operating income (expense), net. From the provided statement, these amounts are $3,578 + $1,462 + $1,096 + $1,000 + $5 = $6,137
R = Total revenue is not explicitly stated but can be found by summing Net sales and Other revenue. From the provided statement, these amounts are $13,806 + $1,000 = $14,806
So, Depreciation and Amortization for FY2017 is:
DA = OE - NI = $6,137 + $(497) = $5,640

Now we can calculate the average of Depreciation and Amortization as a percentage of revenue over the three years:

Average DA/R = (DA_2019 + DA_2018 + DA_2017) / (R_2019 + R_2018 + R_2017)
Average DA/R = ($6,664 + $5,638 + $5,640) / ($16,430 + $14,996 + $14,806)
Average DA/R ≈ 0.27 or 27% (rounded to one decimal place)

question: According to the details clearly outlined within the P&L statement and the cash flow statement, what is the FY2020 - FY2022 3 year average of D&A as a % of revenue for Netflix? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the 3-year average of D&A (Depreciation and Amortization) as a percentage of revenue, we first need to calculate the total D&A for each year and the total revenue for each year. Then, we'll sum these values and divide by the sum of the revenues to get the average.

   Year | D&A | Revenue | D&A/Revenue (%)
   ----|----|--------|-----------------
   2020 | 14,026,132 + 12,230,367 + 10,806,912 = 37,063,411  | (not provided in the data)
   2021 | (not provided in the data)                             | (not provided in the data)
   2022 | (not provided in the data)                             | (not provided in the data)

   Unfortunately, the given data does not provide the revenue figures for each year. To find the average D&A as a percentage of revenue, we need to have both the total D&A and total revenue values for all three years.

question: What is the FY2015 unadjusted EBITDA % margin for Intel? Calculate unadjusted EBITDA using unadjusted operating income and D&A (from cash flow statement). Compute or extract the answer by primarily using the details outlined in the statement of income and the statement of cash flows.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the FY2015 unadjusted EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization) for Intel, we need to find the operating income and depreciation and amortization (D&A) from the provided statements.

  1. Operating Income: This is given directly in the Statement of Income under "Income before provision for income taxes". For FY2015, it is $39,467 million.

  2. Depreciation and Amortization (D&A): D&A is not explicitly provided in the cash flow statement, but we can find it by using the following relationship: Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities = Operating Income + D&A - Changes in Working Capital Items

   - For FY2015, Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities is $36,894 million.
   - Operating Income is $39,467 million.
   - Let's assume the changes in working capital items are zero (this assumption can be refined based on more detailed information). Then D&A would be: D&A = Operating Income - Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities = 39,467 - 36,894 = $2,573 million.

Now that we have the operating income and D&A, we can calculate unadjusted EBITDA:

   - Unadjusted EBITDA = Operating Income + D&A - Interest Expense (not provided in the cash flow statement) - Taxes Expense (not provided in the cash flow statement) = 39,467 + 2,573 - 0 - 0 = $42,040 million.

To find the unadjusted EBITDA margin, we divide the unadjusted EBITDA by net sales (revenue):

   - Net Sales for FY2015 is given as $60,783 million in the Statement of Income.
   - Unadjusted EBITDA Margin = Unadjusted EBITDA / Net Sales = 42,040 / 60,783 = approximately 69.1% (rounded to two decimal places).

question: What is the FY2020 unadjusted EBITDA less capex for Boeing? Define unadjusted EBITDA as unadjusted operating income + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]. Answer in USD billions. Base your judgments on the information provided primarily in the cash flow statement and the P&L statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA less Capex (Capital Expenditures) for FY2020, we first need to find the unadjusted operating income (EBIT), depreciation and amortization (D&A), and capital expenditures from the provided cash flow statement and P&L statement.

1. Unadjusted Operating Income (EBIT): This is calculated as Earnings Before Income Taxes (EBIT) + Income Tax Benefit/(Expense). From the P&L statement, we find that EBIT is 11,604 - (2,156) - (722) - (475) = $8,351 million. The income tax benefit is 2,535 + 1,623 = $4,158 million. So, EBIT = 8,351 + 4,158 = $12,509 million.

2. Depreciation and Amortization (D&A): This is not explicitly provided in the cash flow statement but can be found by looking at the depreciation and amortization expense from the P&L statement. From the P&L statement, we find that D&A expense is 438 + 92 = $530 million.

3. Capital Expenditures (Capex): This is found in the cash flow statement under Investing Activities. Net cash used by investing activities is -18,366. However, this includes investments and other items that are not capital expenditures. To find only the capex, we need to subtract the other items from the total. Unfortunately, the cash flow statement does not provide a breakdown of these other items, so it's impossible to accurately calculate the capex based on the provided information.

Since we cannot find the capex, we cannot calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA less Capex for FY2020 with the given information. It is recommended to check the full financial statements or annual report for more detailed information.

question: What is AES's FY2020 net income % margin? Please utilize information provided primarily within the P&L statement.
label: PASS
answer:
The Net Income for FY2020 is $1,565 million. To calculate the net income margin, we divide the net income by total revenue and multiply by 100.

   Net Income Margin = (Net Income / Total Revenue) * 100%

   Total Revenue for FY2020 is $9,660 million.

   Therefore, the Net Income Margin for FY2020 is approximately 16.3%.

question: You are an investment banker and your only resource(s) to answer the following question is (are): the statement of financial position and the P&L statement. Here's the question: what is CVS Health's FY2020 days inventory outstanding (DIO)? DIO is defined as: 365 * (average inventory between FY2019 and FY2020) / (FY2020 COGS). Round your answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Days Inventory Outstanding (DIO), we need the average inventory for FY2020 and the Cost of Products Sold (COGS) for FY2020. The financial statements provided do not show the inventory balance at the end of each year, but they do provide the Cost of Products Sold (COGS).

   From the P&L statement, we can see that the COGS for FY2020 was $163,981 million.

   Unfortunately, without the inventory balances at the end of each year, it is not possible to calculate the average inventory for FY2020 directly from the provided financial statements. You would need additional information or a different source to find the inventory balances at the end of FY2019 and FY2020.

   Once you have those values, you can calculate the average inventory as follows: (Ending Inventory_FY2019 + Ending Inventory_FY2020) / 2. Then use that value to calculate DIO using the formula provided.

question: We need to calculate a financial metric by using information only provided within the P&L statement and the statement of cash flows. Please answer the following question: what is the FY2019 interest coverage ratio for Kraft Heinz? Define interest coverage ratio as: (unadjusted operating income [from income statement] + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]) / gross interest expense [from income statement]). Round answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Interest Coverage Ratio for FY2019, we need to find the unadjusted operating income, depreciation and amortization, and gross interest expense from the provided statements.

1. Unadjusted Operating Income: This is not explicitly stated in the cash flow statement, but it can be found on the income statement. The net income (line 6) is $3,552, and we need to add back depreciation and amortization (line 44), which is $501. So, unadjusted operating income = Net Income + Depreciation and Amortization = $3,552 + $501 = $4,053

2. Gross Interest Expense: This can be found on the income statement (line 876). So, gross interest expense = $876

Now we can calculate the Interest Coverage Ratio:

Interest Coverage Ratio = (Unadjusted Operating Income + Depreciation and Amortization) / Gross Interest Expense = ($4,053 + $501) / $876 ≈ 5.92

So, the FY2019 Interest Coverage Ratio for Kraft Heinz is approximately 5.92.

contexts:
For the Full Year of Fiscal 2022
Net sales increased 18.3% to $10.2 billion compared to $8.6 billion in fiscal 2021,
primarily due to the favorable impact from the continued resilience of the beauty
category, retail price increases, the impact of new brands and product innovation,
increased social occasions, and fewer COVID-19 limitations compared to fiscal 2021.
Comparable sales increased 15.6% compared to an increase of 37.9% in fiscal 2021,
driven by a 10.8% increase in transactions and a 4.3% increase in average ticket.
Gross profit increased 20.1% to $4.0 billion compared to $3.4 billion in fiscal 2021. As
a percentage of net sales, gross profit increased to 39.6% compared to 39.0% in fiscal
2021, primarily due to leverage of fixed costs, strong growth in other revenue, and
favorable channel mix shifts, partially offset by higher inventory shrink and lower
merchandise margin.
question: Did Ulta Beauty experience higher or lower merchandise margin in FY2023?
ground_truth: Merchandise margin was lower in FY2023.
label: PASS
answer: I don't have information about FY2023 for Ulta Beauty. The data provided is for FY2022, and according to the context, the merchandise margin was lower due to higher inventory shrink and lower merchandise margin as a percentage of net sales.

question: We want to calculate a financial metric. Please help us compute it by basing your answers off of the balance sheet and the P&L statement. Here's the question: what is Johnson & Johnson's FY2020 asset turnover ratio? Asset turnover ratio is defined as: FY2020 revenue / (average total assets between FY2019 and FY2020). Round your answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Asset Turnover Ratio for Johnson & Johnson in FY2020, we first need to find the average total assets for the years 2019 and 2020. Let's assume that the total liabilities and shareholders equity is equal to total assets:

   - Total Assets (FY2019) = $157,728 million
   - Total Assets (FY2020) = $174,894 million

Now let's find the average total assets for the two years:

   Average Total Assets = (Total Assets FY2019 + Total Assets FY2020) / 2
   Average Total Assets = ($157,728 million + $174,894 million) / 2
   Average Total Assets = $166,366.5 million

Next, we need to find the revenue for FY2020:

   - Sales to customers (FY2020) = $82,584 million

Now we can calculate the Asset Turnover Ratio:

   Asset Turnover Ratio (FY2020) = Revenue (FY2020) / Average Total Assets
   Asset Turnover Ratio (FY2020) = $82,584 million / $166,366.5 million
   Asset Turnover Ratio (FY2020) ≈ 0.493 (rounded to two decimal places)

question: What is the FY2016 - FY2018 3 year average of capex as a % of revenue for Apple? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place. Give a solution to the question by using the income statement and the statement of cash flows.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the 3-year average capital expenditures (capex) as a percentage of revenue, we first need to calculate the capex for each year from the provided statements of cash flows, then find the average, and finally convert it into a percentage of revenue.

1. Calculate Capex for each year:
   - FY2016: Cash used in investing activities (line 5) = $(46,446)
   - FY2017: Cash generated by investing activities (line 5) = $16,066
   - FY2018: Cash used in investing activities (line 5) = $(45,977)

2. Calculate the total capex for the 3-year period:
   Capex_total = (Capex_FY2016 + Capex_FY2017 + Capex_FY2018) = $(46,446 - $16,066 - $45,977) = $(103,489)

3. Calculate the total revenue for each year:
   - FY2016: Operating income (line 8) = $70,898
   - FY2017: Operating income (line 8) = $61,344
   - FY2018: Operating income (line 8) = $60,024

4. Calculate the total revenue for the 3-year period:
   Revenue_total = (Revenue_FY2016 + Revenue_FY2017 + Revenue_FY2018) = ($70,898 + $61,344 + $60,024) = $192,266

5. Calculate the 3-year average capex as a percentage of revenue:
   Average_capex_percentage = (Capex_total / Revenue_total) * 100% = ($103,489 / $192,266) * 100% ≈ 53.71%

So the FY2016 - FY2018 3-year average of capex as a % of revenue for Apple is approximately 53.71%.

question: What is Verizon's FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA (using unadjusted operating income and D&A from cash flow statement) % margin? Please base your judgments on the information provided primarily in the statement of income and the cash flow statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization), we need to find the Operating Income (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes) and Depreciation and Amortization (D&A) from the provided statements.

   - Operating Income can be found by subtracting Interest Expense and Provision for income taxes from Income Before Provision For Income Taxes.
   - D&A is listed separately in the cash flow statement under Investing Activities as "Depreciation and amortization expense".

For FY2021:
- Operating Income = Income Before Provision For Income Taxes - Interest Expense - Provision for income taxes
                         = 22,733 - (3,485 + 6,802) = 12,446
- D&A = Depreciation and amortization expense = 17,581

Now we can calculate the Unadjusted EBITDA:
- EBITDA = Operating Income + D&A = 12,446 + 17,581 = $30,027

To find the EBITDA margin, divide the EBITDA by Net Income and multiply by 100:
- EBITDA Margin = (EBITDA / Net Income) * 100%
                      = ($30,027 / 19,265) * 100% = 155.48%

So, Verizon's FY2021 unadjusted EBITDA margin is approximately 155.48%.

question: Based on the information provided primarily in the income statement and the statement of cash flows, what is Apple's FY2021 retention ratio (using total cash dividends paid and net income attributable to shareholders)? Round answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Retention Ratio, we need to find out how much of the company's earnings were retained (not distributed as dividends) and compare it with the total earnings. The formula is: Retention Ratio = (Net Income - Dividends paid) / Net Income

First, let's find the total cash dividends paid for FY2021. Unfortunately, the information provided does not include the dividends paid. However, we can still calculate the retained earnings by assuming that all the cash generated by operating activities was used for either reinvestment or paying off debt (since investing and financing activities show a net increase in cash).

Cash generated by operating activities = 104,038 (from the statement of cash flows)

Now let's assume that all this cash was not distributed as dividends:
Retained Earnings = Cash generated by operating activities - Investing activities - Financing activities
Retained Earnings = 104,038 - (-14,545) - 0 (since there are no financing activities that use cash)
Retained Earnings = 118,583

Now we can calculate the Retention Ratio:
Retention Ratio = (Net Income - Dividends paid) / Net Income
Since we don't know the dividends paid, let's assume that all net income was retained:
Retention Ratio = (Net Income - 0) / Net Income
Retention Ratio = 1

However, this is an assumption since the actual dividends paid are not provided in the information. To get the accurate Retention Ratio, you would need to find the total cash dividends paid for FY2021.

contexts:
Blue Jeans Network, Inc.
In April 2020, we entered into a definitive purchase agreement to acquire Blue Jeans Network, Inc. (BlueJeans), an enterprise-grade video conferencing and event platform,
whose services are sold to Business customers globally. The transaction closed in May 2020. The aggregate cash consideration paid by Verizon at the closing of the
transaction was approximately $397 million, net of cash acquired.
The financial results of BlueJeans are included in the consolidated results of Verizon from the date of acquisition. Revenue related to BlueJeans was approximately
$73 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.
question: In FY 2020, how much did the acquisition of BlueJeans contribute to Verizon's revenue?
ground_truth: Approximately $73 million.
label: PASS
answer: The acquisition of BlueJeans contributed approximately $73 million to Verizon's revenue in FY 2020.

question: We need to calculate a reasonable approximation (or exact number if possible) of a financial metric. Basing your judgment by information plainly provided in the statement of cash flows and the P&L statement, what is Best Buy's FY2019 depreciation and amortization expense (as shown in cash flow statement) divided by total revenue (as a %, rounded to one decimal place)?
label: PASS
answer:
1.464 (Net earnings from continuing operations for FY2019) / 2,184 (Cash, cash equivalents and restricted cash at end of FY2019) = 0.67 (or 67%)

To find the depreciation and amortization expense, we need to look for the adjustment made to reconcile net earnings to total cash provided by operating activities in the cash flow statement. In this case, it is given as 770 (for FY2019).

Now, let's find the total revenue: 1,464 (Net earnings from continuing operations for FY2019) - 424 (Income tax expense for FY2019) = 1,040.

Finally, calculate the percentage by dividing depreciation and amortization expense by total revenue: 770 / 1,040 = 0.74 or 74%. However, since we are asked to round to one decimal place, the answer is approximately 74%.

question: What is the FY2022 SG&A as a % of total revenue for 3M? Give a solution to the question by using the income statement.
label: PASS
answer: The SG&A (Selling, general and administrative expenses) for FY2022 was $9,049 million. The total revenue for FY2022 was $34,229 million. To find the percentage, divide the SG&A by the total revenue and multiply by 100: ($9,049 / $34,229) * 100 = approximately 26.42%.

contexts:
Note 7Stock-Based Compensation
The Company grants stock-based compensation, primarily to employees and non-employee directors. Grants to executive officers are generally
performance-based. Through a series of shareholder approvals, there have been amended and restated plans and new provisions implemented
by the Company. RSUs are subject to quarterly vesting upon retirement or voluntary termination. Employees who attain at least 25 years of
service with the Company receive shares under accelerated vesting provisions on the annual vesting date. The 2019 Incentive Plan authorized
the issuance of 17,500,000 shares (10,000,000 RSUs) of common stock for future grants, plus the remaining shares that were available for grant
and the future forfeited shares from grants under the previous plan, up to a maximum aggregate of 27,800,000 shares (15,885,000 RSUs). The
Company issues new shares of common stock upon vesting of RSUs. Shares for vested RSUs are generally delivered to participants annually,
net of shares withheld for taxes.
The following awards were outstanding at the end of 2022:

3,328,000 time-based RSUs, which vest upon continued employment or service over specified periods of time; and

121,000 performance-based RSUs, of which 82,000 were granted to executive officers subject to the determination of the attainment of
performance targets for 2022. This determination occurred in September 2022, at which time at least 33% of the units vested, as a result
of the long service of all executive officers receiving performance-based RSUs. The remaining awards vest upon continued employment
over specified periods of time.
question: Was there any Incentive Plan put forth for employees?
ground_truth: 2019 Incentive Plan authorized to issue up to 10,000,000 RSUs
label: PASS
answer: Yes, there is an Incentive Plan for employees (the 2019 Incentive Plan).

Dividend Payments
 In fiscal years 2023, 2022, and 2021, we paid $723 million, $732 million, and $742 million, respectively, in dividends. The dividend per share
has increased in each of the years, with the total amount paid declining due to repurchase of shares under announced share buyback programs.

ground_truth: Yes. AMCOR paid $723 million in dividends during FY2023.
label: PASS

To calculate Block's (formerly known as Square) Asset Turnover Ratio for FY2017, we first need to find the average total assets between FY2016 and FY2017. We can do this by adding the total assets at the end of each year and dividing by 2.

   - Total Assets (FY2016): Not provided in the data given.
   - Total Assets (FY2017): 2,214,253 + 1,708,721 = 3,922,974

   Average Total Assets: (3,922,974 / 2) = 1,961,487

Next, we find the total net revenue for FY2017 from the provided data: 1,708,721 + 41,415 = 1,749,136

   Asset Turnover Ratio (FY2017) = Total Net Revenue / Average Total Assets = 1,749,136 / 1,961,487 ≈ 0.89

The Asset Turnover Ratio for Block's FY2017 is approximately 0.89.

Our cash provided from operating activities is somewhat impacted by seasonality. Working capital needs are impacted by sales, which are generally highest
in the fourth quarter due to title release timing and holiday-related sales patterns.
question: Are ATVI's cash inflows consistent on a quarterly basis?
ground_truth: No, they are seasonal in correlation to factors such as game releases and holiday surges
label: PASS
answer: No, Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) cash inflows are not consistent on a quarterly basis due to seasonality.

question: What is Netflix's two year unadjusted EBITDA (using unadjusted operating income + D&A from cash flow statement) CAGR from FY2017 to FY2019 (in units of percents and round to one decimal place)? Give a response to the question by relying on the details shown in the statement of cash flows and the statement of income.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the two-year Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) for Netflix's unadjusted EBITDA, we need to find the operating income and depreciation and amortization (D&A) from the provided statements of income and cash flows, respectively.

First, let's find the operating income for each year:
- FY2017: Operating Income = Net income - Interest + Taxes = 1,536,489 (from Statement of Income) - 599,132 (Interest from Supplemental Disclosure) + 400,658 (Income taxes paid from Supplemental Disclosure) = 2,037,079
- FY2018: Operating Income = Net income - Interest + Taxes = 2,814,501 (from Statement of Income) - 375,831 (Interest from Supplemental Disclosure) + 131,069 (Income taxes paid from Supplemental Disclosure) = 2,307,601
- FY2019: Operating Income = Net income - Interest + Taxes = 2,715,485 (from Statement of Income) - 213,313 (Interest from Supplemental Disclosure) + 113,591 (Income taxes paid from Supplemental Disclosure) = 2,398,581

Next, let's find the D&A for each year:
- FY2017: Depreciation and Amortization = -114,337 (from Cash Flows from Operating Activities)
- FY2018: Depreciation and Amortization = -150,422 (from Cash Flows from Operating Activities)
- FY2019: Depreciation and Amortization = -157,778 (from Cash Flows from Operating Activities)

Now, let's calculate the EBITDA for each year:
- FY2017: EBITDA = Operating Income + D&A = 2,037,079 + (-114,337) = 1,922,742
- FY2018: EBITDA = Operating Income + D&A = 2,307,601 + (-150,422) = 2,157,179
- FY2019: EBITDA = Operating Income + D&A = 2,398,581 + (-157,778) = 2,240,803

To calculate the CAGR for the two-year period (FY2018 to FY2019), we can use the formula:
CAGR = ((EBITDA_2019 / EBITDA_2017)^(1/2)) - 1
CAGR = ((2,240,803 / 1,922,742)^(1/2)) - 1 ≈ 0.15 (rounded to one decimal place)

So, Netflix's two-year unadjusted EBITDA CAGR from FY2017 to FY2019 is approximately 15%.

question: How much, if any, of Paypal's outstanding notes are classified as short-term debt as of Q2 2023?
ground_truth: None of the outstanding notes are classified as short-term debt as of Q2 2023.
label: PASS
answer: There is no information provided about the maturity dates of PayPal's outstanding notes. To classify a debt as short-term, it typically has to mature within one year. Since none of the maturity dates given are before June 9, 2024 (Q3 2023), there is no short-term debt classified as of Q2 2023.

question: Based on the information provided primarily in the P&L statement and the cash flow statement, what is MGM Resorts's FY2019 unadjusted EBITDA less capital expenditures? Define unadjusted EBITDA as unadjusted operating income + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]. Answer in USD thousands.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the unadjusted EBITDA for MGM Resorts International in FY2019, we need to find the Operating Income (EBIT) from the provided P&L statement and add Depreciation and Amortization (D&A) from the cash flow statement.

   - For FY2019:
      1. Operating Income (EBIT): 3,940,215 (from the P&L statement)
      2. Depreciation and Amortization (D&A): 1,304,649 (from the cash flow statement)

   - Calculate unadjusted EBITDA: EBIT + D&A = 3,940,215 + 1,304,649 = 5,244,864 (in USD thousands)

   Now, we need to subtract Capital Expenditures from the unadjusted EBITDA to get the adjusted EBITDA. However, the capital expenditure information is not provided in the given data. Therefore, I cannot provide the adjusted EBITDA value.

   - Adjusted EBITDA = Unadjusted EBITDA - Capital Expenditures (not provided)

question: What is PepsiCo's FY2018 interest coverage ratio? Define interest coverage ratio as: (unadjusted operating income [from income statement] + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]) / gross interest expense [from income statement]). Round answer to two decimal places. Calculate (or extract) the answer from the cash flow statement and the P&L statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Interest Coverage Ratio, we need the following figures: Unadjusted Operating Income, Depreciation and Amortization, and Gross Interest Expense.

1. Unadjusted Operating Income can be found on the Income Statement under "Operating Income" or "Earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT)". I couldn't find this specific figure in the provided data, but let's assume it's 5,000 for simplicity.

2. Depreciation and Amortization can be found under "Depreciation and amortization" on the Cash Flow Statement. In the provided data, it is not explicitly stated, but we can see that depreciation and amortization are included in the "Net Cash Provided by/(Used for) Investing Activities". Since this figure is negative (-7,150), it means that PepsiCo spent more on depreciation and amortization than it received from these activities. Let's assume the total depreciation and amortization expense is 8,000 for simplicity.

3. Gross Interest Expense can be found under "Interest Receivable (if any)" and "Interest Payable" on the Income Statement. Since there are no interest receivables mentioned in the provided data, we'll assume that all interest expenses are under "Interest Payable". The total gross interest expense is the sum of payments of long-term debt, cash tender and exchange offers/debt redemptions, and other financing: (4,007 + 2,504 + 58) = 6,569.

Now we can calculate the Interest Coverage Ratio:
(Unadjusted Operating Income + Depreciation and Amortization) / Gross Interest Expense = (5,000 + 8,000) / 6,569 ≈ 1.24

This means that PepsiCo's FY2018 Interest Coverage Ratio is approximately 1.24. However, it's important to note that the actual ratio might be different due to the assumptions made in this calculation.

question: From the perspective of a public equities analyst, please answer the following question by primarily taking information that is provided in the income statement and the statement of cash flows. What is Costco's three year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a % of revenue from FY2020 to FY2022? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the three-year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue for Costco, we need to calculate the depreciation and amortization expense for each year and then find the average. However, the provided data does not show the depreciation and amortization expense explicitly. Instead, it shows the net cash provided by operating activities, which includes this expense but also other items like changes in working capital.

To estimate the depreciation and amortization expense, we can use the following approach:

1. Calculate the net change in other operating assets and liabilities, net for each year (ignoring the sign since it represents a cash outflow). This item includes depreciation and amortization expense but also other items like changes in accounts payable and accrued expenses.
2. Subtract the net change in other operating assets and liabilities, net from the net cash provided by operating activities for each year to estimate the depreciation and amortization expense.
3. Calculate the average of these estimated depreciation and amortization expenses over the three years.

Here's how we can do it:

FY2020: Net cash provided by operating activities = 8,861; Net change in other operating assets and liabilities, net = 549 + 1,057 + 728 = 2,334. Depreciation and amortization expense (estimated) = 8,861 - 2,334 = 6,527
FY2021: Net cash provided by operating activities = 7,392; Net change in other operating assets and liabilities, net = 1,891 + 1,838 + 2,261 = 5,990. Depreciation and amortization expense (estimated) = 7,392 - 5,990 = 1,392
FY2022: Net cash provided by operating activities = 8,958; Net change in other operating assets and liabilities, net = 1,891 + 1,838 + 728 = 4,557. Depreciation and amortization expense (estimated) = 8,958 - 4,557 = 4,401

Average depreciation and amortization expense over the three years: (6,527 + 1,392 + 4,401) / 3 = 3,921.33

To find the percentage of revenue, we need to know the total revenue for each year. However, the provided data does not show the revenues explicitly. Assuming that the revenues are approximately equal in all three years (which is often the case for Costco), we can estimate the average revenue as follows:

Average revenue over the three years: (Revenue_FY2020 + Revenue_FY2021 + Revenue_FY2022) / 3.

Using this estimated average revenue, we can calculate the three-year average of depreciation and amortization expense as a percentage of revenue: 3,921.33 / (Average revenue over the three years) * 100%

Without knowing the exact revenues for each year, I cannot provide an exact value for this percentage. However, you can use the provided data to estimate the average revenue and then calculate the percentage as shown above.

question: What is the FY2022 cash conversion cycle (CCC) for CVS Health? CCC is defined as: DIO + DSO - DPO. DIO is defined as: 365 * (average inventory between FY2021 and FY2022) / (FY2022 COGS). DSO is defined as: 365 * (average accounts receivable between FY2021 and FY2022) / (FY2022 Revenue). DPO is defined as: 365 * (average accounts payable between FY2021 and FY2022) / (FY2022 COGS + change in inventory between FY2021 and FY2022). Round your answer to two decimal places. Calculate what was asked by utilizing the line items clearly shown in the income statement and the statement of financial position.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC) for CVS Health, we need to find DIO (Days Inventory Outstanding), DSO (Days Sales Outstanding), and DPO (Days Payable Outstanding). Let's start by finding each component:

1. DIO:
   COGS for FY2022 is not provided, but we can calculate it using the Net income attributable to CVS Health and Income from continuing operations attributable to CVS Health:

   COGS = Net income - Income from continuing operations (assuming no change in tax rate)
   COGS = $5.48 (Net income) - $3.16 (Income from continuing operations) = $2.32

   Average inventory for FY2022 and FY2021 is not provided, but we can assume that the average inventory for both years is half of the ending inventory for each year:

   Average Inventory = (Ending Inventory_FY2022 + Ending Inventory_FY2021) / 2
   Average Inventory = ($7,910 + $12) / 2 = $6,455.5

   DIO = 365 * (Average Inventory / COGS) = 365 * ($6,455.5 / $2.32) ≈ 15789 days

2. DSO:
   Average accounts receivable for FY2022 and FY2021 is not provided, but we can assume that the average accounts receivable for both years is half of the ending accounts receivable for each year:

   Average Accounts Receivable = (Ending AR_FY2022 + Ending AR_FY2021) / 2
   Average Accounts Receivable = ($7,910 + $13) / 2 = $6,455.5

   DSO = 365 * (Average Accounts Receivable / Revenue) = 365 * ($6,455.5 / $7,910) ≈ 381 days

3. DPO:
   Average accounts payable for FY2022 and FY2021 is not provided, but we can assume that the average accounts payable for both years is half of the ending accounts payable for each year:

   Average Accounts Payable = (Ending AP_FY2022 + Ending AP_FY2021) / 2
   Average Accounts Payable = ($67,807 + $69,736) / 2 = $68,766.5

   DPO = 365 * (Average Accounts Payable / (COGS + Change in Inventory)) = 365 * ($68,766.5 / ($2.32 * 365 + $6,455.5 - $6,455.5)) ≈ 190 days

Now that we have the values for DIO, DSO, and DPO, we can calculate the Cash Conversion Cycle (CCC):

CCC = DIO + DSO - DPO = 15789 + 381 - 190 ≈ 15478 days or approximately 42.6 years. This is a very long cash conversion cycle, which means that CVS Health has a relatively slow turnover of inventory and accounts receivable compared to accounts payable.

contexts:
PART I
Item 1. Business
The Boeing Company, together with its subsidiaries (herein referred to as Boeing, the Company, we, us, our), is one of the worlds major
aerospace firms.
We are organized based on the products and services we offer. We operate in four reportable segments:

Commercial Airplanes (BCA);

Defense, Space & Security (BDS);

Global Services (BGS);

Boeing Capital (BCC).
Commercial Airplanes Segment
This segment develops, produces and markets commercial jet aircraft principally to the commercial airline industry worldwide. We are a leading
producer of commercial aircraft and offer a family of commercial jetliners designed to meet a broad spectrum of global passenger and cargo
requirements of airlines. This family of commercial jet aircraft in production includes the 737 narrow-body model and the 767, 777 and 787 wide-
body models. We ended production of the 747 wide-body model in 2022. Development continues on the 777X program and the 737-7 and 737-
10 derivatives.
Defense, Space & Security Segment
This segment engages in the research, development, production and modification of manned and unmanned military aircraft and weapons
systems for strike, surveillance and mobility, including fighter and trainer aircraft; vertical lift, including rotorcraft and tilt-rotor aircraft; and
commercial derivative aircraft, including anti-submarine and tanker aircraft. In addition, this segment engages in the research, development,
production and modification of the following products and related services: strategic defense and intelligence systems, including strategic missile
and defense systems, command, control, communications, computers, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (C4ISR), cyber and
information solutions, and intelligence systems, satellite systems, including government and commercial satellites and space exploration.
Global Services Segment
This segment provides services to our commercial and defense customers worldwide. BGS sustains aerospace platforms and systems with a full
spectrum of products and services, including supply chain and logistics management, engineering, maintenance and modifications, upgrades
and conversions, spare parts, pilot and maintenance training systems and services, technical and maintenance documents, and data analytics
and digital services.
Boeing Capital Segment
BCC seeks to ensure that Boeing customers have the financing they need to buy and take delivery of their Boeing product, while managing
overall financing exposure. BCCs portfolio consists of equipment under operating leases, sales-type/finance leases, notes and other
receivables, assets held for sale or re-lease and investments.
question: What are the major products and services that Boeing sells as of FY2022?
ground_truth: Boeing's main product offerings are Commercial Jet Aircraft and Military Aircraft and weapons systems. Main service offerings are services allied to product offerings and product financing.
label: PASS
answer:
1. Commercial Airplanes (737 narrow-body model, 767, 777, and 787 wide-body models)
2. Military aircraft and weapons systems for various purposes (fighter and trainer aircraft, vertical lift, rotorcraft, tilt-rotor aircraft, commercial derivative aircraft like anti-submarine and tanker aircraft)
3. Strategic defense and intelligence systems, satellite systems, space exploration products and related services
4. Services to commercial and defense customers worldwide (supply chain and logistics management, engineering, maintenance and modifications, upgrades and conversions, spare parts, pilot and maintenance training, technical and maintenance documents, data analytics and digital services)
5. Financing solutions for Boeing customers (equipment under operating leases, sales-type/finance leases, notes and other receivables, assets held for sale or re-lease and investments)

contexts:
Products Gross Margin
Products gross margin increased during 2022 compared to 2021 due primarily to a different Products mix and higher Products 
volume, partially offset by the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.
Products gross margin percentage increased during 2022 compared to 2021 due primarily to a different Products mix, partially 
offset by the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.
Services Gross Margin
Services gross margin increased during 2022 compared to 2021 due primarily to higher Services net sales, partially offset by the 
weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.
Services gross margin percentage increased during 2022 compared to 2021 due primarily to improved leverage and a different 
Services mix, partially offset by the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar
question: What drove gross margin change as of FY 2022 for Apple? If gross margin is not a useful metric for a company like this, then please state that and explain why.
ground_truth: Apple's gross margins increased during 2022 due to the product mix, product volume, and service net sales increase
label: PASS
answer: The gross margin for both Products and Services increased in FY 2022 compared to 2021 at Apple. This was primarily driven by changes in product/service mix, higher volumes, improved leverage, and higher net sales. The increase was partially offset by the weakness of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.

contexts:
Divestitures
During 2022, proceeds from disposals of businesses, equity method investments and nonmarketable securities totaled $458 million, which primarily related to the refranchising
of our bottling operations in Cambodia. We received net cash proceeds of $228 million and recognized a net gain of $153 million as a result of the refranchising. Also included
was the sale of our ownership interest in one of our equity method investees, for which we received cash proceeds of $123 million and recognized a net gain of $13 million.
question: Were there any divestitures of Coca-Cola in FY2022?
ground_truth: Divestitures amounted to $458 million which mainly related to Coca-Cola's refranchising in Cambodia
label: PASS
answer: Yes, there were divestitures of Coca-Cola in FY2022.

contexts:
Deferred RevenuesOur deferred revenues primarily relate to advance payments received or receivable from various government or government sponsored customers in international
markets for supply of Comirnaty. The deferred revenues related to Comirnaty total $2.5 billion as of December 31, 2022, with $2.4 billion and $77 million recorded in current liabilities and
noncurrent liabilities, respectively. The deferred revenues related to Comirnaty totaled $3.3 billion as of December 31, 2021, with $3.0 billion and $249 million recorded in current liabilities
and noncurrent liabilities, respectively. The decrease in Comirnaty deferred revenues during 2022 was primarily the result of amounts recognized in Revenues as we delivered the product
to our customers and the impact of foreign exchange, partially offset by additional advance payments received as we entered into new or amended contracts. During 2022, we recognized
revenue of $3.1 billion that was included in the balance of Comirnaty deferred revenues as of December 31, 2021. The Comirnaty deferred revenues as of December 31, 2022 will be
recognized in Revenues proportionately as we transfer control of the product to our customers and satisfy our performance obligation under the contracts, with the amounts included in
current liabilities expected to be recognized in Revenues within the next 12 months, and the amounts included in noncurrent liabilities expected to be recognized in Revenues in 2024.
Deferred revenues associated with contracts for other products were not significant as of December 31, 2022 or 2021.
question: What brought about the change in Pfizer's deferred revenues of FY2022 vs FY2021?
ground_truth: Pfizer's deferred revenues went down by $547 million, this change was related to the decrease in Comirnaty deferred revenues during 2022 which is primarily the result of amounts recognized in Revenues as the company delivered the product to Pfizer's customers and the impact of foreign exchange, partially offset by additional advance payments received as we entered into new or amended contracts.
label: PASS
answer: The decrease in Pfizer's deferred revenues from Comirnaty was primarily due to amounts recognized in Revenues as product was delivered, foreign exchange impact, and additional advance payments received. This was partially offset by new or amended contracts.

question: What is 3M's FY2018 unadjusted EBITDA less capital expenditures? Define unadjusted EBITDA as unadjusted operating income + depreciation and amortization [from cash flow statement]. Answer in USD millions. Address the question by using the line items and information shown within the statement of cash flows and the P&L statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To find the unadjusted EBITDA for FY2018, we need to calculate the operating income (Earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT) first. We can find this by adding Net income including noncontrolling interest back with Interest expense (not provided in the given data).

  1. Calculate EBIT:
     - Net income including noncontrolling interest: $5,363 million
     - Interest expense (not provided in the data)
       (Assuming it's given elsewhere as $X million)
     - EBIT = Net income + Interest expense = $5,363 + X

  2. Calculate unadjusted EBITDA:
     - Depreciation and amortization (not provided in the data)
       (Assuming it's given elsewhere as $Y million)
     - Unadjusted EBITDA = EBIT + Depreciation + Amortization = EBIT + Y

  3. Since we don't have the interest expense and depreciation/amortization values, we cannot calculate the unadjusted EBITDA using the provided data.

contexts:
Competition
The commercial jet aircraft market and the airline industry remain extremely competitive. We face aggressive international competitors who are
intent on increasing their market share, such as Airbus and entrants from China.
question: Was Boeing faced with new competition in FY2022?
ground_truth: Yes. In FY2022 Boeing was faced with new competition from Chinese entrants into the commercial jet aircraft market .
label: PASS
answer: Yes, Boeing faced new competition in FY2022, particularly from Airbus and entrants from China.

question: What is Corning's FY2018 unadjusted EBITDA (unadjusted operating income + depreciation and amortization from the cash flow statement)? Report answer in USD billions. Give a solution to the question by using the P&L statement and the cash flow statement.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate Corning's FY2018 unadjusted EBITDA, we need to find the operating income (EBIT) from the Profit and Loss Statement and add depreciation and amortization expenses from the Cash Flow Statement.

From the P&L statement:
- Income before income taxes is $1,503 for FY2018.
- Provision benefit for income taxes is $(437) for FY2018.
- So, EBIT (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes) = Income before income taxes + Provision benefit for income taxes = $1,503 - $437 = $1,066 million.

From the Cash Flow Statement:
- Depreciation and amortization expenses are not explicitly listed in the cash flow statement. However, we can find them by using the following relationship: Net income (loss) + Depreciation and amortization expenses = Net cash provided by operating activities.
- From the Cash Flow Statement, we see that Net cash provided by operating activities for FY2018 is $3,692 million.
- Since Net income (loss) for FY2018 is $1,066 million, Depreciation and amortization expenses = Net cash provided by operating activities - Net income (loss) = $3,692 - $1,066 = $2,626 million.

Now we can calculate the unadjusted EBITDA:
- EBITDA = EBIT + Depreciation and amortization expenses = $1,066 + $2,626 = $3,692 million.

question: Assuming you only had access to the cash flow statement and the P&L statement, please answer the following question: what is the retention ratio (using total cash dividends paid and net income attributable to shareholders) for eBay's FY2020? Round answer to two decimal places.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the Retention Ratio, we need to find out the amount of Net Income Attributable to Shareholders and the Cash Dividends Paid.

1. Net Income Attributable to Shareholders: From the provided data, we can see that for FY2020, the Net Income is $5,667 million.

2. Cash Dividends Paid: Unfortunately, the cash dividends paid are not explicitly provided in the given statements. However, we can find the information about the repayment of debt and issuance of common stock which might help us estimate the cash dividends if they were paid from these sources. Since there is no clear indication that the cash flows from financing activities were used for dividend payments, I will assume that eBay did not pay any dividends in FY2020.

In this case, the Retention Ratio would be 100% (as Net Income Retained = Total Net Income and Dividends Paid = 0). However, it is essential to note that this assumption about no cash dividends paid might not be accurate, as the information provided does not confirm or deny this. To get a precise answer, you would need more detailed financial statements or additional information about the company's dividend policy.

question: Does Boeing have an improving gross margin profile as of FY2022? If gross margin is not a useful metric for a company like this, then state that and explain why.
ground_truth: Yes. Boeing has an improving gross margin profile as of FY2022. Gross profit improved from $3,017 million in FY2021 to $3,502 million in FY2022. Gross margin % improved from 4.8% in FY2021 to 5.3% in FY2022.
label: PASS
answer: Yes, Boeing has an improving gross margin profile as of FY2022. The gross margin (Total revenues - Total costs and expenses) for FY2022 was $3,502 million, compared to $3,017 million in FY2021. This represents a 14% increase in the gross margin from one year to the next.

question: What is Costco's three year average of capital expenditures as a % of revenue from FY2015 to FY2017? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place. Calculate what was asked by utilizing the line items clearly shown in the statement of cash flows and the statement of income.
label: PASS
answer:
To calculate the three-year average of capital expenditures as a percentage of revenue, we need to find the total capital expenditures for each year and then divide that by the net sales (revenue) for each year. The line items for capital expenditures are shown in the statement of cash flows under "Repayments of long-term debt" (which includes capital expenditures), and the net sales (revenue) is shown in the income statement.

   Year | Capital Expenditures (millions) | Net Sales (millions) | Capital Expenditures as a % of Revenue
   ----|-------------------------------|---------------------|---------------------------------
   2015 | 1,125 - 1 (repayments of long-term debt) = 1,124 | Net sales not provided in the given data | Not calculable
   2016 | 185 + 74 (excess tax benefits on stock-based awards) - 486 (repurchases of common stock) = 395 | Net sales not provided in the given data | Not calculable
   2017 | 1,125 + 86 (excess tax benefits on stock-based awards) - 481 (repurchases of common stock) = 1,212 | $112,093 (Net sales attributable to Costco from the income statement) | 1.07%

   Since we don't have net sales data for years 2015 and 2016, we can only calculate the capital expenditures as a percentage of revenue for year 2017. To find the three-year average, we would need to obtain the net sales figures for those years.

contexts:
Overview
JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPMorgan Chase or the Firm, 
NYSE: JPM), a financial holding company incorporated under 
Delaware law in 1968, is a leading financial services firm 
based in the United States of America (U.S.), with 
operations worldwide. JPMorgan Chase had $3.7 trillion in 
assets and $292.3 billion in stockholders equity as of 
December 31, 2022. The Firm is a leader in investment 
banking, financial services for consumers and small 
businesses, commercial banking, financial transaction 
processing and asset management. Under the J.P. Morgan 
and Chase brands, the Firm serves millions of customers, 
predominantly in the U.S., and many of the worlds most 
prominent corporate, institutional and government clients 
globally.
JPMorgan Chases principal bank subsidiary is JPMorgan 
Chase Bank, National Association (JPMorgan Chase Bank, 
N.A.), a national banking association with U.S. branches in 
48 states and Washington, D.C. JPMorgan Chases principal 
non-bank subsidiary is J.P. Morgan Securities LLC (J.P. 
Morgan Securities), a U.S. broker-dealer. The bank and non-
bank subsidiaries of JPMorgan Chase operate nationally as 
well as through overseas branches and subsidiaries, 
representative offices and subsidiary foreign banks. The 
Firms principal operating subsidiaries outside the U.S. are 
J.P. Morgan Securities plc and J.P. Morgan SE (JPMSE), 
which are subsidiaries of JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. and are 
based in the United Kingdom (U.K.) and Germany, 
respectively.
The Firms website is www.jpmorganchase.com. JPMorgan 
Chase makes available on its website, free of charge, annual 
reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and 
current reports on Form 8-K pursuant to Section 13(a) or 
Section 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as 
soon as reasonably practicable after it electronically files or 
furnishes such material to the U.S. Securities and Exchange 
Commission (the SEC) at www.sec.gov. JPMorgan Chase 
makes new and important information about the Firm 
available on its website at https://www.jpmorganchase.com, 
including on the Investor Relations section of its website at 
https://www.jpmorganchase.com/ir. Information on the 
Firm's website is not incorporated by reference into this 
Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended 
December 31, 2022 (2022 Form 10-K or Form 10-K) or 
the Firms other filings with the SEC. The Firm has adopted, 
and posted on its website, a Code of Conduct for all 
employees of the Firm and a Code of Ethics for its Chairman 
and Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Principal 
Accounting Officer and all other professionals of the Firm 
worldwide serving in a finance, accounting, treasury, tax or 
investor relations role. The Code of Ethics is also available in 
print upon request to the Firms Investor Relations team. 
Within the time period required by the SEC, JPMorgan Chase 
will post on its website any amendment to the Code of Ethics 
and any waiver applicable to a director or executive officer.
question: What are the geographies that JPM primarily operates in as of FY 2022?
ground_truth: JPM mainly operated in the US.
label: PASS
answer: United States, United Kingdom, Germany (and overseas branches and subsidiaries, representative offices, and subsidiary foreign banks in various locations).

question: What is the FY2015 - FY2017 total revenue 2 year CAGR for Verizon? Answer in units of percents and round to one decimal place. Address the question by adopting the perspective of a financial analyst who can only use the details shown within the income statement.
label: PASS
answer: The 2-year Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) for Total Revenue from FY2015 to FY2017 is approximately 1.4%. To calculate this, you would find the average of the percentage differences between consecutive years: ((33,060 - 131,620)/(131,620*2)) * 100 = -18.5%, ((131,620 - 125,980)/(125,980*2)) * 100 = 2.4%, and then take the average of these two values: (-18.5% + 2.4%) / 2 = 1.4%.
